properties.title: Identity card
properties.description:
By: Mahmoud Darwish
Birth date: March 13, 1941
Setting: takes place at a security checkpoint
Description: The poem "Identity Card" is about a Palestinian man explaining his identity
to an Israeli of social (it is implied they are at a security checkpoint). In his description, he
describes his family, work situation, and history, lamenting the loss of his homeland.

properties.title: Postcard from Kashmir
properties.description:
By: Agha Shahid Ali
Birth date: February 4, 1949
Setting: Kashmir
Description: 'Postcard from Kashmir' is the opening poem from the Volume The
Half-Inch Himalaya (1987). In this poem, the poet stresses the distance and longing from
home in the very first line. Kashmir- the beloved homeland has metaphorically shrunk
and is now ironically reduced to a postcard.

properties.title: Where The Mind Is Without Fear:
properties.description:
(Poem)
By: Rabindranath Tagore
Birth date: May 7, 1861
Setting: India
Description: The poet begins with these words to see the idealized vision of his home
country. He said no one in his country should ever live in constant Fear. Instead, they
should be bold and confident in themselves. Knowledge should be available to all citizens

properties.title: And Still I Rise
properties.description:
By: Maya Angelou
Birth date: April 4, 1928
Setting: America in the late twentieth century
Description: Still I Rise” is primarily about self-respect and confidence. In the poem,
Angelou reveals how she will overcome anything through her self-esteem. She shows how
nothing can get her down. She will rise to any occasion and nothing, not even her skin
color, will hold her back

properties.title: The End of Exile
properties.description:
By: Solmaz Sharif
Birth date: 1983
Setting: US 
Description: Sharif wanders her ancestral city and hears a man selling something she
doesn't have a word for: “this thing: a without which // I cannot name. // Without which is
my life.” A preposition becomes a noun, because the gap between languages has become
an object itself.

properties.title: The king's elephant
properties.description:
By: Saadallah Wannous
Birth date: 1941
Description: The story is set in an unnamed country under a repressive dictatorship
ruled by a tyrannical leader referred to as "The Chief." The Chief's reign is characterized
by fear, censorship, and the suppression of dissent.
Characters: Hamza, The Chief, Hamza's Collaborators, Government Of icials, Citizens
and The King.

properties.title: The Guest
properties.description:
By: Albert Camus
Translated by: Justin O'Brien
Birth date: November 7, 1913
Setting: Isolated schoolhouse
Description: The protagonist of "The Guest" is Daru, a schoolteacher who lives in a
remote schoolhouse in a desolate area of the Algerian countryside. Daru is a quiet and
introspective man who values solitude and independence. The story begins with Daru
receiving an order from the French colonial authorities to transport an Arab prisoner,
named Balducci, to a nearby police station.
Characters: Daru, The Arab Prisoner and Balducci.

properties.title: The Whale Rider
properties.description:
By: Witi Ihimaera
Birth date: February 7, 1944
Setting: Whangara, a Māori community on the eastern edge of New Zealand's North
Island
Description: The plot follows the story of Paikea Apirana. The village leader should be
the first-born son, a direct patrilineal descendant of Paikea, the Whale Rider, who rode
on top of a whale (Tohora) from Hawaiki. Pai was originally born a twin, but her twin
brother and her mother died during childbirth. Pai is female and so technically cannot
inherit the leadership. While her grandfather, Koro, later forms an af ectionate bond with
his granddaughter, carrying her to school every day on his bicycle, he also condemns her
and blames her for conflicts within the tribe.
Characters: Kahu Paikea Apirana (Kahu), Koro Apirana (Koro), Nanny Flowers
(Nanny), Rawiri Apirana (Uncle Rawiri), Porourangi Apirana (Porourangi) and Rangi
Apirana

properties.title: His First Ball
properties.description:
By:Witi Ihimaera
Birth date: February 7, 1944
Setting: New Zealand
Description: "His First Ball" by Witi Ihimaera is a coming-of-age story that follows
Matiu, a young Maori boy from a rural background, as he prepares for and attends his
first formal ball in an urban setting. With the guidance of his mother and Aunt Adelaide,
Matiu navigates the unfamiliar world of formal events, encountering social expectations
and romantic aspirations along the way.
Characters: Matiu, Matiu's Mother, Aunt Adelaide, Miss Sonja.

properties.title: The Lottery
properties.description:
Setting: Small, unnamed village in rural America
Author: Shirley Jackson
Birth Date: December 14, 1916
Description: "The Lottery" is set in a seemingly idyllic small town where the annual ritual of the lottery takes a dark and chilling turn. The story explores themes of tradition, mob mentality, and the banality of evil.
Characters: Various villagers including Mr. Summers, Mr. Hutchinson, Tessie Hutchinson, Bill Hutchinson, Old Man Warner, and others.

properties.title: The Metamorphosis
properties.description:
Setting: Unspecified European city, likely Prague (Kafka's hometown)
Author: Franz Kafka
Birth Date: July 3, 1883
Description: "The Metamorphosis" tells the story of Gregor Samsa, a traveling salesman who wakes up one morning to find himself transformed into a monstrous insect. The novella explores themes of alienation, existentialism, and the absurdity of human existence.
Characters: Gregor Samsa, Mr. Samsa (his father), Mrs. Samsa (his mother), Grete Samsa (his sister), and the chief clerk.

properties.title: The Gift of the Magi
properties.description:
Setting: New York City, United States (early 20th century)
Author: O. Henry (pen name for William Sydney Porter)
Birth Date: September 11, 1862
Description: "The Gift of the Magi" is a heartwarming tale about a young couple, Jim and Della, who each sacrifice their most prized possession to buy a Christmas gift for the other. The story explores themes of selflessness, love, and the true meaning of giving.
Characters: Jim Young, Della Young.

properties.title: The Necklace
properties.description:
Setting: France, late 19th century
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Birth Date: August 5, 1850
Description: "The Necklace" follows the story of Madame Loisel, a woman who borrows a necklace to wear to a high-society event, only to lose it. The story explores themes of pride, social class, and the consequences of deceit.
Characters: Mathilde Loisel, Monsieur Loisel, Madame Forestier.

properties.title: The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock
properties.description:
Setting: Urban landscape, possibly inspired by cities like London or Boston
Author: T.S. Eliot
Birth Date: September 26, 1888
Description: "The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock" is a modernist poem that presents the fragmented thoughts and musings of its protagonist, Prufrock, as he navigates a world of social alienation and existential uncertainty. The poem explores themes of isolation, indecision, and the search for meaning.
Characters: J. Alfred Prufrock (the speaker).

properties.title: Ozymandias
properties.description:
Setting: Ancient Egypt, possibly near the ruins of a colossal statue
Author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
Birth Date: August 4, 1792
Description: "Ozymandias" is a sonnet that narrates the encounter of a traveler with the ruins of a statue of the ancient Egyptian pharaoh Ozymandias (Ramses II). Through the crumbling monument, the poem reflects on the transient nature of power and the inevitable decline of human achievements.
Characters: The traveler who encounters the ruins of the statue of Ozymandias.

properties.title: Kubla Khan
properties.description:
Setting: Xanadu, the summer palace of the Mongol ruler Kublai Khan, located in modern-day Inner Mongolia, China
Description: "Kubla Khan" is a fragmentary poem that describes the poet's vision of a mythical and exotic landscape inspired by the palace and gardens of Kublai Khan. It explores themes of creativity, imagination, and the power of the natural world.

properties.title: The Second Coming
properties.description:
associated with Ireland and the tumultuous period following World War I
Description: "The Second Coming" is a prophetic poem that reflects on the chaos and uncertainty of the modern world. Yeats uses vivid imagery and symbolism to evoke a sense of impending apocalypse, exploring themes of political upheaval, spiritual crisis, and the collapse of traditional values.

properties.title: In Flanders Fields
properties.description:
Setting: The battlefields of World War I, particularly in Flanders (Belgium)
Description: "In Flanders Fields" is a war poem written during World War I that pays tribute to the soldiers who died in battle. McCrae's haunting verses describe the poppies that grow amidst the graves of fallen soldiers, serving as a powerful symbol of remembrance and sacrifice.

properties.title: Hamlet
properties.description: Description: "Hamlet" is one of Shakespeare's most famous tragedies, telling the story of Prince Hamlet's quest for revenge against his uncle Claudius, who has murdered Hamlet's father, the king, and married Hamlet's mother, Queen Gertrude. The play explores themes of revenge, madness, and the complexity of human nature.

properties.title: A Doll's House
properties.description:
Author: Henrik Ibsen
Description: "A Doll's House" follows the story of Nora Helmer, a young wife and mother who becomes disillusioned with her role in her marriage and society. The play explores themes of gender roles, societal expectations, and the quest for personal identity and autonomy.

properties.title: Cry, the Beloved Country
properties.description:
Genre: Novel
Description: "Cry, the Beloved Country" is a powerful novel that explores the impact of apartheid on South African society. Set in the 1940s, it tells the story of Stephen Kumalo, a Zulu pastor, and his journey to Johannesburg to find his son, Absalom, who has become involved in crime. The novel delves into themes of racial injustice, social inequality, and the search for reconciliation.

properties.title: Master Harold...and the Boys
properties.description:
Author: Athol Fugard
Genre: Play
Description: Set in 1950s South Africa, "Master Harold...and the Boys" explores the relationship between a young white boy, Hally, and the two black servants, Sam and Willie, who work at his family's tearoom. As the play unfolds, it exposes the deep-seated racial tensions and the complexities of power dynamics under apartheid.

properties.title: The Grass is Singing
properties.description:
by Doris Lessing
Genre: Novel
Description: "The Grass is Singing" is a novel that examines the racial and social dynamics of colonial Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe). The story centers on Mary Turner, a white woman living on a farm, and her troubled relationship with her black servant, Moses. Through their interactions, the novel explores themes of racism, power, and identity.

properties.title: Disgrace
properties.description:
Author: J.M. Coetzee
Birth date: 9th februery 1940 
Setting: The novel is primarily set in post-apartheid South Africa, with locations including Cape Town, the Eastern Cape region, and rural farmland areas.

properties.title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
properties.description:
Setting: The fictional town of Macondo, inspired by the Colombian Caribbean region
Author: Gabriel García Márquez
Birth Date: March 6, 1927
Description: "One Hundred Years of Solitude" is a landmark novel in magical realism that follows the multi-generational story of the Buendía family in the fictional town of Macondo. The novel weaves together elements of fantasy, mythology, and history to explore themes of love, power, memory, and the cyclical nature of time.
Characters: The Buendía family including José Arcadio Buendía, Úrsula Iguarán, Aureliano Buendía, Colonel Aureliano Buendía, Remedios the Beauty, and many others.

properties.title: The House of the Spirits
properties.description:
Setting: Chile, spanning from rural villages to urban cities
Author: Isabel Allende
Birth Date: August 2, 1942
Description: "The House of the Spirits" is a family saga that traces the lives of the Trueba family over several generations in an unnamed South American country (implicitly Chile). The novel incorporates elements of magical realism and explores themes of love, power, politics, and social upheaval.
Characters: The Trueba family including Esteban Trueba, Clara del Valle, Alba Trueba, Pedro Tercero García, and other members of the extended family.

properties.title: Ficciones
properties.description:
Setting: Varied, including Buenos Aires, Argentina, and various imaginary or fantastical landscapes
Author: Jorge Luis Borges
Birth Date: August 24, 1899
Description: "Ficciones" is a collection of short stories by Argentine author Jorge Luis Borges, known for his innovative use of metafiction, labyrinthine plots, and philosophical themes. The stories often blur the lines between reality and fiction, exploring concepts such as infinity, identity, and the nature of storytelling.
Characters: Various characters across Borges's short stories, including fictional versions of himself, historical figures, and mythical beings.

properties.title: The Feast of the Goat
properties.description:
Setting: Dominican Republic, primarily in the capital city of Santo Domingo
Author: Mario Vargas Llosa
Birth Date: March 28, 1936
Description: "The Feast of the Goat" is a historical novel that interweaves the narratives of various characters during the final days of the dictatorship of Rafael Trujillo in the Dominican Republic. The novel explores themes of power, corruption, violence, and the legacy of authoritarianism.
Characters: Various characters including Rafael Trujillo, Urania Cabral, and members of Trujillo's inner circle, as well as fictionalized versions of historical figures.

properties.title: Hopscotch
properties.description:
Setting: Primarily in Paris, France, but also includes scenes set in Buenos Aires, Argentina
Author: Julio Cortázar
Birth Date: August 26, 1914
Description: "Hopscotch" is a novel that experiments with narrative structure and reader participation. The story follows Horacio Oliveira, an Argentine intellectual living in Paris, and his interactions with a diverse cast of characters. The novel offers multiple reading paths, allowing readers to choose their own journey through the narrative.
Characters: Horacio Oliveira, La Maga, and various other characters encountered by the protagonist throughout the novel.
